props.code:
const products = [
  { id: "candy", name: "Candy", price: 10, onSale: true },
  { id: "ice-cream", name: "Ice cream", price: 20, onSale: true },
  { id: "cake", name: "Cake", price: 30, onSale: false },
  { id: "donuts", name: "Donuts", price: 12, onSale: true },
  { id: "chocolate", name: "Chocolate", price: 15, onSale: false },
  { id: "flower", name: "Flower", price: 40, onSale: false },
  { id: "sofa", name: "Sofa", price: 120, onSale: true },
  { id: "bed", name: "Bed", price: 400, onSale: true },
];

children.value: 가격이 30 이하인 제품 중에서 3개를 뽑고 그 가격들의 총합을 구하기.

props.code:
pipe(
  products,
  map((a) => a.price), // Lazy
  filter((p) => p < 30), // Lazy
  take(3),
  reduce(add),
  console.log,
);

children.value: 해당 코드에서 map, filter는 Generator 를 사용하였기 때문에 take가 3개를 만족하게 되면 더이상 실행되지 않는다.

함수 f와 g를 합성한다고 할때, 수학적인 기호로는 다음과 같이 표시한다.

props.code: f * g

children.value: 이론적으로는 f(g(x)) 를 합성한 결과는 언제 어디서 실행하든지 항상 f(g(x))가 되어야 하지만, 현실 에서는
여러가지 외부적인 요인(메모리누수, API 서버 고장 등)으로 인해 같지 않을 수 있다

f(g(x)) == f(g(x)) // 이론
f(g(x)) != f(g(x)) // 현실

f(g(x)) != f(g(x)) // 현실
모나드는 함수합성을 안전하게 하기위한 목적을 가지고 만든 객체(Object)다. 이 객체가 map을 메소드로 가지고 있으면 functor(함수자), map과 flatMap을 메소드로 가지고 있으면 monad라고 정의하였지만 이것은 그냥 정의일 뿐.

f(g(x)) == 실행안함      // 비어있는 배열인 경우
Array 모나드는 다음과 같은 목적으로 만들어진 모나드

props.code:
const g = (a) => a + 1;
const f = (a) => a * a;

[1]
  .map(g)
  .map(f)
  .forEach((a) => console.log(a)); // 4

[1, 2, 3]
  .map(g)
  .map(f)
  .forEach((a) => console.log(a)); // 4, 9, 16

[]
  .map(g)
  .map(f)
  .forEach((a) => console.log(a)); // 아무일도 안함

children.value: Promise 도 Monad의 관점에서 바라본다면 다음과 같다

f(g(x)) == f(g(x))     // 일반적인 경우
f(g(x)) == g(x)        // 비동기중 오류가 발생했을때 합성을 중지

f(g(x)) == g(x)        // 비동기중 오류가 발생했을때 합성을 중지

When using e2e testing in my work, we faced the issue of a lot of code being duplicated. To solve this problem, we defined a dedicated new design pattern for e2e test.
Before start, I would inform you that our company is using two different concept of components:
When using e2e testing in my work, we faced the issue of a lot of code being duplicated. To solve this problem, we defined a dedicated new design pattern for e2e test.
Before start, I would inform you that our company is using two different concept of components:

is a set of multiple components and it takes in charge of a feature of your app such as

As explained above, Model is a specification of module. This folder has
which will import all models under
We can also create some useful model for e2e test under
folder. For example, our project has
. Highly recommended to create more model if you think some codes are used in many places of e2e test.
Scenario is a file where we write the scenario we want to test. Simply put, a scenario can be thought of as a set of models.

The test file refers to a file that defines what we ultimately want to test. There may be one or multiple scenarios in a test file. You can also include model if scenario doesn't cover specific case of your test.

title: How to automate semantic version of your project
description: Semantic Versioning, often abbreviated as SemVer, provides a standardized way to indicate the compatibility and impact of updates, making it easier for developers and users to understand how a new version of a software component relates to previous versions.

children.value: Semantic Versioning, often abbreviated as SemVer, provides a standardized way to indicate the compatibility and impact of updates, making it easier for developers and users to understand how a new version of a software component relates to previous versions.
Semantic Versioning consists of three main components:

props.code: [Major].[Minor].[Patch]

children.value: , such as breaking changes or significant new features that require modification in how the software is used.
are added in a backward-compatible manner or when there are significant improvements.
backward-compatible bug fixes, patches, or minor improvements
that don't introduce new features or breaking changes.
Automate semantic versioning of your project with @semantic-release
package to my colleagues to automate our projects versioning. It is very convenient since it is simple to set up and automatically creates
according to the commit message. Before using this package you must follow the structured rules of commit messages.
Every commit message you write in your project consists of
part. And each part should be divided by empty line.

props.code:
<type>(<scope(optional)>): <short summary>
  │       │                      │
  │       │                      └─⫸ Summary of commit
  │       │
  │       └─⫸ Commit Scope: define where the commit belongs to (optional)
  │
  └─⫸ Commit Type: build|ci|docs|feat|fix|perf|refactor|test|chore

children.value:
<type>(<scope(optional)>): <short summary>
  │       │                      │
  │       │                      └─⫸ Summary of commit
  │       │
  │       └─⫸ Commit Scope: define where the commit belongs to (optional)
  │
  └─⫸ Commit Type: build|ci|docs|feat|fix|perf|refactor|test|chore
: Changes that affect the build system or external dependencies (example scopes: npm)
: Changes to our CI configuration files and scripts (examples: CircleCi, SauceLabs)
: A code change that improves performance
: A code change that neither fixes a bug nor adds a feature
: Adding missing tests or correcting existing tests
: this will be ignore by the semantic release process and not appear in the changelog
explain why you are making the change.
The footer can contain information about breaking changes and deprecations and is also the place to reference GitLab issues and other PRs that this commit closes or is related to.

props.code:
# If your MR has big changes and need to bump up a major version
BREAKING CHANGE: <breaking change summary>

# If your MR make feature deprecated
DEPRECATED: <what is deprecated>

children.value: # If your MR has big changes and need to bump up a major version
# If your MR make feature deprecated

props.code: yarn add -D semantic-release @semantic-release/changelog @semantic-release/git @semantic-release/gitlab

children.value: // The branch where semantic-release check your commits
Test in local (Must set dryRun true in

props.code: yarn semantic-release

children.value: If there is at least one
commit, the minor version is incremented.

props.code:
# version updated X.0.X -> X.1.0
feat: some feature update
feat: some feature update2

children.value: commit,  the patch version is incremented.

props.code:
# version updated X.X.0 -> X.X.1
fix: some fix
refactor: some refactor..
fix: some fix2

semantic-release:
  stage: deploy
  needs: ['unit-tests']
  interruptible: true
  rules:
    - if: $CI_PIPELINE_SOURCE == "push" && $CI_COMMIT_BRANCH == $PROD_BRANCH
      when: on_success
    - when: never
  script:
    - yarn semantic-release

title: How to Resolve Bugs Caused by Conflicts Between Previous and Current Built Assets in SPA
description: Every time when you release a new web app, the bundler generates a random hash filename for each build assets. This allows the server to deliver new assets to the web app without conflicts and avoid asset conflicts with previous versions. However, this behavior can be problematic in SPA(Single page application) where the entire page does not refresh in the browser.

children.value: Every time when you release a new web app, the bundler such as Webpack, Rollup generates a

This allows the server to deliver new assets to the web app without conflicts and avoid asset conflicts with previous versions. However, this behavior can be problematic in SPA(Single page application) where the entire page does not refresh in the browser.
you just released a new version of your SPA while users are using it

. In a typical SPA, code splitting is applied. So, only after the user requests a new page your app will start to fetch new assets such as new scripts, CSS, or images. Unfortunately, your SPA will try to fetch old assets that have already disappeared from the server, and unless he refreshes the browser, he will just be staring at a white screen.

My company Luko's web app had an interface that accepted new input by moving on to the next step after the user completed input. And every time a new web app was released, there was a bug that prevented users from moving on to the next step.
Every time when you release a new web app, the bundler such as Webpack, Rollup generates a

This allows the server to deliver new assets to the web app without conflicts and avoid asset conflicts with previous versions. However, this behavior can be problematic in SPA(Single page application) where the entire page does not refresh in the browser.
you just released a new version of your SPA while users are using it

. In a typical SPA, code splitting is applied. So, only after the user requests a new page your app will start to fetch new assets such as new scripts, CSS, or images. Unfortunately, your SPA will try to fetch old assets that have already disappeared from the server, and unless he refreshes the browser, he will just be staring at a white screen.

My company Luko's web app had an interface that accepted new input by moving on to the next step after the user completed input. And every time a new web app was released, there was a bug that prevented users from moving on to the next step.
came up with the following idea to solve this problem.
Build a new version of the app. New assets are created in the
Copy the newly created assets and place them in a folder named
Get the previous version of assets and move them to the
Currently, the assets that were just built and the assets of the previous version coexist in the
Save the assets in new-assets somewhere and use them when building a new file.
The most important key point of this idea is that both previously built assets and current assets
folder. This way, users can use the previous version of the app without issue until they reload the page.
where to store the old and new assets
, and we ended up creating a new git repository
The script below is the one we run after the app is built in CI/CD.

props.code:
#!/bin/bash
rm -rf cached-assets
mkdir cached-assets

# Pull old assets
cd cached-assets
git config --global user.email "your@email.com"
git config --global user.name "your name"
git init
git pull https://oauth2:${GITLAB_TOKEN}@gitlab.com/SOME/PATH/cached-assets.git BRANCH_NAME
cd ..

# Move new asset to temp
# dist/assets -> .tmp/
rm -rf .tmp
mkdir .tmp
cp -r dist/assets/* .tmp/

# Put old assets with current asset
mv cached-assets/* dist/assets/

# Force update cached-asset
cd cached-assets
rm -rf .git
git init
git checkout -b BRANCH_NAME
cd ..

mv .tmp/* cached-assets/
cd cached-assets
git add -A
git commit -m "update cached assets"
git push -f https://oauth2:${GITLAB_TOKEN}@gitlab.com/SOME/PATH/cached-assets.git BRANCH_NAME

## delete .tmp, cached-assets folder
cd ..
rm -rf .tmp
rm -rf cached-assets

children.value: # Put old assets with current asset

title: 6 Reasons Why I Prefer FxTS Over Lodash or Ramda
description: Today, as someone who loves functional programming, I’m going to introduce a functional library FxTs that I’m sure you’ll never know. A few years ago I stumbled upon an online functional programming course authored by “Indong Yoo” who created FxJs(previous version of FxTs) taught functional programming while creating a functional library from scratch.

children.value: Today, as someone who loves functional programming, I’m going to introduce a functional library
that I’m sure you’ll never know. A few years ago I stumbled upon an online functional programming course authored by “
” who created FxJs(previous version of FxTs) taught functional programming while creating a functional library from scratch.

Thanks to this chance, I came to understand the goals and principles of FxTs, and I was fascinated by the beauty of functional programming 😍. After that, I started to use actively this library for my personal vue2/vue3 projects and it resulted in my code being more readable and easier to maintain.

For this reason, I’m thinking of using this library for one of my projects which gonna be migrated soon from nuxt2 to nuxt3 because vue3’s composition API is matched well with the functional programming patterns.
is a paradigm to create clean, readable code by combining small functions with no side effects.

With functional programming, we can replace the imperative programming approach with code that is more readable and maintainable. For example, let’s say you gonna create a function getMalesAge that selects only n males from the user list and gets the sum of their ages.
// Make function `getMalesAge` that selects `n` males and returns the sum of their ages.

What we need to pay attention to here is that loop statements (for, while), conditional statements (if), and control statements (break) can be written by functions ONLY. We can write the code more declaratively rather than do it indicating how sumAge or count variables are changed.
The above functional style example was written using FxTs. Those functions such as
have already been curried as the most functional libraries did. The usage of functional libraries is generally similar, so once you know one, you can quickly use the other.
There are famous functional libraries such as lodashFP and Ramda, but I highly recommend “FxTs” for the following reasons.
Why I recommend you FxTs and not LodashFP, Ramda?
FxTs vs LodashFP vs Ramda performance comparison
First of all, all the functions in FxTs perfectly support the ES6 specification
It delays the creation of the collection until the last and evaluates it at the end
. This brings performance advantages that other libraries do not have, such as lodashFP or Ramda.
If you actually measure the performance, you can see that FxTs is significantly faster than Ramda and slightly faster than Lodash. This difference becomes larger as the size of the array increases.

props.alt: Performance test Ramda vs lodash vs FxTs

children.value: Why there is such a big difference? To investigate it, let’s insert
function in the middle to know how FxTs works. The tap function is also implemented in Ramda and it’s used when you want to check how the value changes in the middle of function composition.

As you can see that FxTs outputs an iterator, unlike Ramda which outputs an array. That means, Ramda creates an array whenever map, filter are executed, which is why Ramda’s performance is significantly lower than FxTs.
You might notice that there is toArray in FxTs at the last step of function composition. It helps to convert an iterator into an array.
If you want to retrieve the actual value inside the iterator for debugging purposes, you can use the peek function in the middle of piping in FxTs.
However, there is something to be aware of: lazy evaluation is not always performant. If we remove take of the above example, the results are reversed.

props.alt: Performance test Ramda vs lodash vs FxTs 2

children.value: function that converts an iterator into an array takes a lot of time. Lazy evaluation is good when you need to perform an operation by extracting only a part of a lot of array data. Otherwise, it is better to use with native JS Array API.
FxTs vs LodashFP vs Ramda performance comparison2

props.alt: Performance test Ramda vs lodash vs FxTs vs FxTs with vanilla

children.value: Therefore, it is important to know at which moment lazy evaluation can achieve maximum performance.
If you want to know more about how does iterator protocol works with FP, I recommend you to read
asynchronous test Fxts vs LodashFP vs Ramda

FxTs has a super convenient way to deal with async/sync functions. You can easily implement Promise.all in the form of functional programming, and furthermore, it is possible to control how many functions are executed using the

LodashFP and Ramda do not support asynchronous functions in the library itself. This is because it is not designed to receive a Promise object when creating a library in the first place. If the code below is executed with lodashFP or Ramda, the
However, FxTs internally check whether it is a
when retrieving a value from an array through an iterator. If the value is a

props.code:
// Async with FxTs example
await Fx.pipe(
  [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
  Fx.toAsync, // convert iterator into asyncIterator
  Fx.map((a) => new Promise((resolve) => resolve(a))),
  Fx.filter((a) => new Promise((resolve) => resolve(a % 2))),
  Fx.take(3) // [1, 3, 5]
  Fx.toArray,
)

children.value: For this reason, when using other libraries than FxTs, functions must be implemented by yourself to check
// Create your own filter to unwrap Promise
FxTs also has a very cool feature
. In the case of the above example, 5 asynchronous functions are executed simultaneously like
function, you can control how many asynchronous functions are executed at the same time.
Error handling test FxTs vs LodashFP vs Ramda
Handling errors well is directly related to the robust program. In FxTs, all errors can be handled using
For example, assuming that there is null in the middle of the data array where the object should exist. When accessing the null property in Ramda and lodashFP, the corresponding error does not go to
and the library itself breaks down.

If you have the basic knowledge of functional programming and understand the iterator protocol, you can start functional programming with FxTs. Since it is designed to implement only for the data type in JS without implementing Functor or Monad separately, it does not require a deep understanding of the relevant library or functional programming, so it is perfect for an FP beginner.
You just need to understand 2 basic concepts in FxTs:
uses lazy evaluation, returns an iterator, and is used at the beginning or in the middle of function composition.
uses immediate evaluation, returns a value, and is used at the end of function composition.

props.code:
Fx.pipe(
  [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
  map((a) => a * 2), // Lazy (return iterator)
  filter((a) => a % 2), // Lazy (return iterator)
  toArray // Strict (return array)
)

Fx.pipe(
  [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
  map((a) => a * 2), // Lazy (return iterator)
  filter((a) => a % 2), // Lazy (return iterator)
  reduce((a, b) => a + b) // Strict (return number)
)

Fx.pipe(
  [1, 2, 3, 4, 5],
  map((a) => a * 2), // Lazy (return iterator)
  filter((a) => a % 2), // Lazy (return iterator)
  each(console.log) // Strict (print console)
)

children.value: are used at the beginning or middle of function composition, and Strict functions are used at the last to make meaningful value. You can see the list of Lazy and Strict functions
FxTs consists of only functions essential for functional programming, so it is suitable for an introduction to functional programming.
that do not exist in Vanilla JavaScript and aims for lightweight functional programming only with basic JavaScript types and
FxTs has recently been registered in
and it is getting popular. Of course, it is not yet as popular as LodashFP or Ramda, but it is worthy of being widely used considering the above reasons I have mentioned so far.
FxTs is an open-source library developed by
dev team, and its popularity is increasing in Korea thanks to developer Indong Yoo’s functional programming lecture.
For those who are interested in FxTs through this article, I have linked the Slack community as a reference. It’s still a fresh library, so if you’d like to contribute, maybe now is a chance
